remixlab.proscene
Class Scene

java.lang.Object
  remixlab.proscene.Scene

public class Scene
extends java.lang.Object

A 3D interactive Processing scene.

A Scene has a full reach Camera, it can be used for on-screen or off-screen rendering purposes (see the different constructors), and it has two means to manipulate objects: an interactiveFrame() single instance (which by default is null) and a mouseGrabber() pool.

Usage

To use a Scene you have three choices:
  1. Direct instantiation. In this case you should instantiate your own Scene object at the PApplet.setup() function. See the example BasicUse.
  2. Inheritance. In this case, once you declare a Scene derived class, you should implement proscenium() which defines the objects in your scene. Just make sure to define the PApplet.draw() method, even if it's empty. See the example AlternativeUse.
  3. External draw handler registration. You can even declare an external drawing method and then register it at the Scene with addDrawHandler(Object, String). That method should return void and have one single Scene parameter. This strategy may be useful when there are multiple viewers sharing the same drawing code. See the example StandardCamera.

Interactivity mechanisms

Proscene provides two interactivity mechanisms to manage your scene: global keyboard shortcuts and camera profiles.
  1. Global keyboard shortcuts provide global configuration options such as drawGrid() or drawAxis() that are common among the different registered camera profiles. To define a global keyboard shortcut use setShortcut(Character, KeyboardAction) or one of its different forms. Check setDefaultShortcuts() to see the default global keyboard shortcuts.
  2. Camera profiles represent a set of camera keyboard shortcuts, and camera and frame mouse bindings which together represent a "camera mode". The scene provide high-level methods to manage camera profiles such as registerCameraProfile(CameraProfile), unregisterCameraProfile(CameraProfile) or currentCameraProfile() among others. To perform the configuration of a camera profile see the CameraProfile class documentation.

Animation mechanisms

Proscene provides three animation mechanisms to define how your scene evolves over time:
  1. Overriding the animate() method. In this case, once you declare a Scene derived class, you should implement animate() which defines how your scene objects evolve over time. See the example Animation.
  2. External animation handler registration. You can also declare an external animation method and then register it at the Scene with addAnimationHandler(Object, String). That method should return void and have one single Scene parameter. See the example AnimationHandler.
  3. By querying the state of the animatedFrameWasTriggered variable. During the drawing loop, the variable animatedFrameWasTriggered is set to true each time an animated frame is triggered (and to false otherwise), which is useful to notify the outside world when an animation event occurs. See the example Flock.

    Constructor Detail

    Scene

    public Scene(PApplet p)
    Constructor that defines an on-screen Scene (the one that most likely would just fulfill all of your needs). All viewer parameters (display flags, scene parameters, associated objects...) are set to their default values. See the associated documentation. This is actually just a convenience function that simply calls this(p, (PGraphicsOpenGL) p.g). Call any other constructor by yourself to possibly define an off-screen Scene.

    See Also:
    Scene(PApplet, PGraphicsOpenGL), Scene(PApplet, PGraphicsOpenGL, int, int)

    Scene

    public Scene(PApplet p,
             PGraphicsOpenGL renderer)
    This constructor is typically used to define an off-screen Scene. This is accomplished simply by specifying a custom renderer, different from the PApplet's renderer. All viewer parameters (display flags, scene parameters, associated objects...) are set to their default values. This is actually just a convenience function that simply calls this(p, renderer, 0, 0). If you plan to define an on-screen Scene, call Scene(PApplet) instead.

    See Also:
    Scene(PApplet), Scene(PApplet, PGraphicsOpenGL, int, int)

    Scene

    public Scene(PApplet p,
             PGraphicsOpenGL renderer,
             int x,
             int y)
    This constructor is typically used to define an off-screen Scene. This is accomplished simply by specifying a custom renderer, different from the PApplet's renderer. All viewer parameters (display flags, scene parameters, associated objects...) are set to their default values. The x and y parameters define the position of the upper-left corner where the off-screen Scene is expected to be displayed, e.g., for instance with a call to the Processing built-in image(img, x, y) function. If isOffscreen() returns false (i.e., renderer() equals the PApplet's renderer), the values of x and y are meaningless (both are set to 0 to be taken as dummy values). If you plan to define an on-screen Scene, call Scene(PApplet) instead.

    See Also:
    Scene(PApplet), Scene(PApplet, PGraphicsOpenGL)

    init

    public void init()
    This method is called before the first drawing happen and should be overloaded to initialize stuff not initialized in PApplet.setup(). The default implementation is empty.

    Typical usage include camera() initialization (showAll()) and Scene state setup (setAxisIsDrawn(boolean) and setGridIsDrawn(boolean).

    proscenium

    public void proscenium()
    The method that actually defines the scene.

    If you build a class that inherits from Scene, this is the method you should overload, but no if you instantiate your own Scene object (in this case you should just overload PApplet.draw() to define your scene).

    The processing camera set in pre() converts from the world to the camera coordinate systems. Vertices given in draw() can then be considered as being given in the world coordinate system. The camera is moved in this world using the mouse. This representation is much more intuitive than a camera-centric system (which for instance is the standard in OpenGL).

    mouseGrabberPool

    public java.util.List<MouseGrabbable> mouseGrabberPool()
    Returns a list containing references to all the active MouseGrabbers.

    Used to parse all the MouseGrabbers and to check if any of them MouseGrabbable.grabsMouse() using MouseGrabbable.checkIfGrabsMouse(int, int, Camera).

    You should not have to directly use this list. Use removeFromMouseGrabberPool(MouseGrabbable) and addInMouseGrabberPool(MouseGrabbable) to modify this list.

    Returns the associated Camera, never null.

    mouseGrabber

    public MouseGrabbable mouseGrabber()
    Returns the current MouseGrabber, or null if none currently grabs mouse events.

    When MouseGrabbable.grabsMouse(), the different mouse events are sent to it instead of their usual targets ( camera() or interactiveFrame()).

    setMouseGrabber

    protected void setMouseGrabber(MouseGrabbable mouseGrabber)
    Directly defines the mouseGrabber().

    You should not call this method directly as it bypasses the MouseGrabbable.checkIfGrabsMouse(int, int, Camera) test performed by #mouseMoved(MouseEvent).

    isInMouseGrabberPool

    public boolean isInMouseGrabberPool(MouseGrabbable mouseGrabber)
    Returns true if the mouseGrabber is currently in the mouseGrabberPool() list.

    When set to false using removeFromMouseGrabberPool(MouseGrabbable), the Scene no longer MouseGrabbable.checkIfGrabsMouse(int, int, Camera) on this mouseGrabber. Use addInMouseGrabberPool(MouseGrabbable) to insert it back.

    addInMouseGrabberPool

    public void addInMouseGrabberPool(MouseGrabbable mouseGrabber)
    Adds the mouseGrabber in the mouseGrabberPool().

    All created InteractiveFrames (which are MouseGrabbers) are automatically added in the mouseGrabberPool() by their constructors. Trying to add a mouseGrabber that already isInMouseGrabberPool(MouseGrabbable) has no effect.

    Use removeFromMouseGrabberPool(MouseGrabbable) to remove the mouseGrabber from the list, so that it is no longer tested with MouseGrabbable.checkIfGrabsMouse(int, int, Camera) by the Scene, and hence can no longer grab mouse focus. Use isInMouseGrabberPool(MouseGrabbable) to know the current state of the MouseGrabber.

    removeFromMouseGrabberPool

    public void removeFromMouseGrabberPool(MouseGrabbable mouseGrabber)
    Removes the mouseGrabber from the mouseGrabberPool().

    See addInMouseGrabberPool(MouseGrabbable) for details. Removing a mouseGrabber that is not in mouseGrabberPool() has no effect.

    clearMouseGrabberPool

    public void clearMouseGrabberPool()
    Clears the mouseGrabberPool().

    Use this method only if it is faster to clear the mouseGrabberPool() and then to add back a few MouseGrabbers than to remove each one independently.

    hasMouseTracking

    public boolean hasMouseTracking()
    Returns true if DesktopEvents.mouseMoved(java.awt.event.MouseEvent) is called even when no mouse button is pressed.

    You need to setMouseTracking() to \c true in order to use MouseGrabber (see mouseGrabber()).

    setMouseTracking

    public void setMouseTracking(boolean enable)
    Sets the hasMouseTracking() value.

    frustumEquationsUpdateIsEnable

    public boolean frustumEquationsUpdateIsEnable()
    Returns true if automatic update of the camera frustum plane equations is enabled and false otherwise. Computation of the equations is expensive and hence is disabled by default.

    See Also:
    toggleFrustumEquationsUpdate(), disableFrustumEquationsUpdate(), enableFrustumEquationsUpdate(), enableFrustumEquationsUpdate(boolean), Camera.updateFrustumEquations()

    toggleFrustumEquationsUpdate

    See Also:

    pre

    public void pre()
    Paint method which is called just before your PApplet.draw() method. This method is registered at the PApplet and hence you don't need to call it.

    Sets the processing camera parameters from camera() and updates the frustum planes equations if enableFrustumEquationsUpdate(boolean) has been set to true.

    draw

    public void draw()
    Paint method which is called just after your PApplet.draw() method. This method is registered at the PApplet and hence you don't need to call it. Calls drawCommon().

    See Also:
    drawCommon()

    drawCommon

    protected void drawCommon()
    Internal method. Called by draw() and beginDraw().

    First performs any scheduled animation, then calls proscenium() which is the main drawing method that could be overloaded. Then, if there's an additional drawing method registered at the Scene, calls it (see addDrawHandler(Object, String)). Finally, displays the displayGlobalHelp(), the axis, the grid, the interactive frames' selection hints and camera paths, and some visual hints (such drawZoomWindowHint(), drawScreenRotateLineHint() and drawArcballReferencePointHint()) according to user interaction and flags.

    See Also:
    proscenium(), addDrawHandler(Object, String), gridIsDrawn(), axisIsDrwn, addDrawHandler(Object, String), addAnimationHandler(Object, String)

    hollowCylinder

    public void hollowCylinder(int detail,
                           float w,
                           float h,
                           PVector m,
                           PVector n)
    Draws a cylinder whose bases are formed by two cutting planes (m and n), along the renderer() positive z axis.

    Parameters:
    detail -
    w - radius of the cylinder and h is its height
    h - height of the cylinder
    m - normal of the plane that intersects the cylinder at z=0
    n - normal of the plane that intersects the cylinder at z=h
    See Also:
    cylinder(float, float)

                 float r2,
                 float h)
    Draws a truncated cone along the renderer() positive z axis, with its base centered at (x,y), height h, and radii r1 and r2 (basis and height respectively).

    See Also:
    cone(int, float, float, float, float)

    drawCamera

    public void drawCamera(Camera camera,
                       int color,
                       boolean drawFarPlane)
    Convenience function that simply calls drawCamera(camera, color, drawFarPlane, 1.0f)

    See Also:
    drawCamera(Camera, int, boolean, float)

    drawCamera

    public void drawCamera(Camera camera,
                       int color,
                       boolean drawFarPlane,
                       float scale)
    Draws a representation of the camera in the renderer() 3D virtual world using color.

    The near and far planes are drawn as quads, the frustum is drawn using lines and the camera up vector is represented by an arrow to disambiguate the drawing.

    When drawFarPlane is false, only the near plane is drawn. scale can be used to scale the drawing: a value of 1.0 (default) will draw the Camera's frustum at its actual size.

    Note: The drawing of a Scene's own Scene.camera() should not be visible, but may create artifacts due to numerical imprecisions.

    beginScreenDrawing

    public void beginScreenDrawing()
    Computes the world coordinates of an screen object so that drawing can be done directly with 2D screen coordinates.

    All screen drawing should be enclosed between beginScreenDrawing() and endScreenDrawing(). Then you can just begin drawing your screen shapes (defined between PApplet.beginShape() and PApplet.endShape()).

    Note: To specify a (x,y) vertex screen coordinate you should first call PVector p = coords(new Point(x, y)) then do your drawing as vertex(p.x, p.y, p.z).

    Attention: If you want your screen drawing to appear on top of your 3d scene then draw first all your 3d before doing any call to a beginScreenDrawing() and endScreenDrawing() pair.

    See Also:
    endScreenDrawing(), coords(Point)

    endScreenDrawing

    public void endScreenDrawing()
    Ends screen drawing. See beginScreenDrawing() for details.

    See Also:
    beginScreenDrawing(), coords(Point)

    coords

    public PVector coords(Point p)
    Computes the world coordinates of the p screen Point.

    This method is only useful when drawing directly on screen. It should be used in conjunction with beginScreenDrawing() and endScreenDrawing() (which may be consulted for details).

    The method beginScreenDrawing() should be called before, otherwise a runtime exception is thrown.

    See Also:
    beginScreenDrawing(), endScreenDrawing(), coords(Point)

    unSetTimerFlag

    protected void unSetTimerFlag()
    Called from the timer to stop displaying the point under pixel and arcball reference point visual hints.

    registerCameraProfile

    public boolean registerCameraProfile(CameraProfile cp)
    Registers a camera profile. Returns true if succeeded. If there's a registered camera profile with the same name, registration will fail.

    Attention: This method doesn't make current cp. For that call setCurrentCameraProfile(CameraProfile).

    Parameters:
    cp - camera profile
    See Also:
    setCurrentCameraProfile(CameraProfile), unregisterCameraProfile(CameraProfile)

    unregisterCameraProfile

    public boolean unregisterCameraProfile(CameraProfile cp)
    Convenience function that simply returns unregisterCameraProfile(cp.name()).

    unregisterCameraProfile

    public boolean unregisterCameraProfile(java.lang.String cp)
    Unregisters the given camera profile by its name. Returns true if succeeded. Registration will fail in two cases: no camera profile is registered under the provided name, or the camera profile is the only registered camera profile which mode is different than THIRD_PERSON.

    The last condition above guarantees that there should always be registered at least one camera profile which mode is different than THIRD_PERSON.

    Parameters:
    cp - camera profile
    Returns:
    true if succeeded

    cameraProfile

    public CameraProfile cameraProfile(java.lang.String name)
    Returns the camera profile which name matches the one provided. Returns null if there's no camera profile registered by this name.

    Parameters:
    name - camera profile name
    Returns:
    camera profile object

    cursorIsHiddenOnFirstPerson

    public boolean cursorIsHiddenOnFirstPerson()
    Returns true if the cursor is hidden in the first person camera profile (meaning that the Scene.MouseAction.LOOK_AROUND mouse action whill be performed by just moving the mouse) and false otherwise.

    See Also:
    hideCursorOnFirstPerson(boolean), toggleCursorHiddenOnFirstPerson()

    toggleCursorHiddenOnFirstPerson

    public void toggleCursorHiddenOnFirstPerson()
    Toggles cursorIsHiddenOnFirstPerson().

    See Also:
    hideCursorOnFirstPerson(boolean)

    hideCursorOnFirstPerson

    public void hideCursorOnFirstPerson(boolean hide)
    Hides the cursor on the first person camera profile if hide is true, otherwise shows it. Default behaviour is to show the cursor on the first person camera profle.

    If the cursor is hidden in the first person camera profile the Scene.MouseAction.LOOK_AROUND mouse action will be performed by just moving the mouse. The Scene.MouseAction.LOOK_AROUND mouse action binding is never changed by a call to this method.

    Attention: If the cursorIsHiddenOnFirstPerson() maybe you'd want to disable mouse tracking (i.e., by a call to setMouseTracking(boolean)) which doesn't seem to make too much sense when the mouse cursor is not shown.

    nextCameraProfile

    public void nextCameraProfile()
    Sets the next registered camera profile as current.

    Camera profiles are ordered by their registration order.

    The methods sought are: keyPressed, keyReleased, and keyTyped.

    setDefaultShortcuts

    public void setDefaultShortcuts()
    Sets global default keyboard shortcuts and the default key-frame shortcut keys.

    Default global keyboard shortcuts are:

    • 'a': Scene.KeyboardAction.DRAW_AXIS.
    • 'e': Scene.KeyboardAction.CAMERA_TYPE.
    • 'g': Scene.KeyboardAction.DRAW_GRID.
    • 'h': Scene.KeyboardAction.GLOBAL_HELP
    • 'H': Scene.KeyboardAction.CURRENT_CAMERA_PROFILE_HELP
    • 'r': Scene.KeyboardAction.EDIT_CAMERA_PATH.
    • space bar: Scene.KeyboardAction.CAMERA_PROFILE.

    Default key-frame shortcuts keys are:

    • '[1..5]': Play path [1..5].
    • 'CTRL'+'[1..5]': Add key-frame to path [1..5].
    • 'ALT'+'[1..5]': Remove path [1..5].

    frameRate

    public float frameRate()
    Returns the target frame rate.

    See Also:
    setFrameRate(float, boolean)

    setFrameRate

    public void setFrameRate(float fRate)
    Convenience function that simply calls setFrameRate(fRate, true).

    See Also:
    setFrameRate(float, boolean)

    setFrameRate

    public void setFrameRate(float fRate,
                         boolean restart)
    Specifies the number of frames to be displayed every second. If the processor is not fast enough to maintain the specified rate, it will not be achieved.

    For example, the function call setFrameRate(30) will attempt to refresh 30 times a second. It is recommended to set the frame rate within setup(). If restart is true and animationIsStarted() then restartAnimation() is called.

    The default rate is 60 frames per second.

    animationIsStarted

    public boolean animationIsStarted()
    Return true when the animation loop is started.

    Proscene animation loop relies on processing drawing loop. The draw() function will check when animationIsStarted() and then called the animation handler method (set with addAnimationHandler(Object, String)) or animate() (if no handler has been added to the scene) every animationPeriod() milliseconds. In addition, During the drawing loop, the variable animatedFrameWasTriggered is set to true each time an animated frame is triggered (and false otherwise), which is useful to notify to the outside world when an animation event occurs.

    Be sure to call loop() before an animation is started.

    Note: The drawing frame rate may be modified when startAnimation() is called, depending on the animationPeriod().

    Use startAnimation(), stopAnimation() or toggleAnimation() to change this value.

    See Also:
    startAnimation(), addAnimationHandler(Object, String), animate()

    animationPeriod

    public float animationPeriod()
    The animation loop period, in milliseconds. When animationIsStarted(), this is the delay that takes place between two consecutive iterations of the animation loop.

    This delay defines a target frame rate that will only be achieved if your animate() and draw() methods are fast enough. If you want to know the maximum possible frame rate of your machine on a given scene, setAnimationPeriod(float) to 1, and startAnimation(). The display will then be updated as often as possible, and the frame rate will be meaningful.

    Default value is 16.6666 milliseconds (60 Hz) which matches processing default frame rate.

    Note: This value is taken into account only the next time you call startAnimation(). If animationIsStarted(), you should stopAnimation() first. See restartAnimation() and setAnimationPeriod(float, boolean).

    See Also:
    setAnimationPeriod(float, boolean)

    setAnimationPeriod

    public void setAnimationPeriod(float period)
    Convenience function that simply calls setAnimationPeriod(period, true).

    See Also:
    setAnimationPeriod(float, boolean)

    setAnimationPeriod

    public void setAnimationPeriod(float period,
                               boolean restart)
    Sets the animationPeriod(), in milliseconds. If restart is true and animationIsStarted() then restartAnimation() is called.

    Note: The drawing frame rate could be modified when startAnimation() is called depending on the animationPeriod().

    See Also:
    startAnimation()

    stopAnimation

    public void stopAnimation()
    Stops animation.

    Warning: Restores the PApplet frame rate to its default value, i.e., calls parent.frameRate(60).

    See Also:
    animationIsStarted()

    startAnimation

    public void startAnimation()
    Starts the animation loop.

    Syncs the drawing frame rate according to animationPeriod(): If the animation frame rate (which value depends on the animationPeriod()) is higher than the current frameRate(), the frame rate is modified to match it, i.e., each drawing frame will trigger exactly one animation event. If the animation frame rate is lower than the frameRate(), the frame rate is left unmodified, and the animation frames will be interleaved among the drawing frames in intervals needed to achieve the target animationPeriod() (provided that your animate() and draw() methods are fast enough).

    See Also:
    animationIsStarted()

    restartAnimation

    public void restartAnimation()
    Restart the animation.

    Simply calls stopAnimation() and then startAnimation().

    performAnimation

    protected void performAnimation()
    Internal use.

    Calls the animation handler. Calls animate() if there's no such a handler. Sets the value of animatedFrameWasTriggered to true or false depending on whether or not an animation event was triggered during this drawing frame (useful to notify the outside world when an animation event occurs).

    See Also:
    animationPeriod(), startAnimation()

    animate

    public void animate()
    Scene animation method.

    When animationIsStarted(), this method defines how your scene evolves over time.

    Overload it as needed. Default implementation is empty. You may addAnimationHandler(Object, String) instead.

    Note that remixlab.proscene.KeyFrameInterpolator (which regularly updates a Frame) do not use this method.

    See Also:
    addAnimationHandler(Object, String).

    toggleAnimation

    public void toggleAnimation()
    Calls startAnimation() or stopAnimation(), depending on animationIsStarted().

    addAnimationHandler

    public void addAnimationHandler(java.lang.Object obj,
                                java.lang.String methodName)
    Attempt to add an 'animation' handler method to the Scene. The default event handler is a method that returns void and has one single Scene parameter.

    Parameters:
    obj - the object to handle the event
    methodName - the method to execute in the object handler class
    See Also:
    animate()

    removeAnimationHandler

    public void removeAnimationHandler()
    Unregisters the 'animation' handler method (if any has previously been added to the Scene).

    See Also:
    addAnimationHandler(Object, String)

    hasRegisteredAnimationHandler

    public boolean hasRegisteredAnimationHandler()
    Returns true if the user has registered an 'animation' handler method to the Scene and false otherwise.

    setPProjectionMatrix

    protected void setPProjectionMatrix()
    Sets the processing camera projection matrix from camera(). Calls PApplet.perspective() or PApplet.orhto() depending on the Camera.type().

    setPModelViewMatrix

    protected void setPModelViewMatrix()
    Sets the processing camera matrix from camera(). Simply calls PApplet.camera().
